lg.l: Saying, the pleasant, young summer [season] has arrived,
[the summer] who is the joyful companion of the king Māraṉ [God of love],
Of excellence worthy of praise; who sat distinctly [= royall] [as] kings [in]
Maturai with storeyed houses, the great Uṟantai,
The bustling Vañci and Pukār with sounding floods,
In the good land of cool floods
That cut [across] the boundaries [= borders] of the Tamiḻ country,
[With] the hill of the tall one and the ocean of the braceleted lady;
Because the young, wind messenger that was begotten by
The great sage of the wealthy Potiyil mountain sounded his music [= commanded]
The war herald who was the Koel of the groves, dense with creepers,
Speaking words of submission [= commanding], as though saying
To the army of the young man with a victorious banner [with] a crocodile,
[Hence], as Kōvalaṉ sulked amongst the [commotion of] sea-bathing,
Mātavi with long eyes like big blossoms,
-Having returned without joining him - having desired [so],
Climbing [up] to the summer room on the top floor,
Which was high, so that it touched the sky,
Because [she] with eminent jewels had the nature of paying her tribute,
[By wearing only] pearls of the southern sea and sandal of the southern mountains,
Lifting [those] gifts of faultless excellence upon her lustrous bosom
With vermillion on the front part [of her] breasts,
Taking in [her] hand the lute of an unshaking tradition,
She sang a Maturakītam song. Feeling faint,
[Thus] becoming she who sat in the Talaikkaṇ Virutti posture
Among the nine Virutti postures, that was suitable [among] the good types [of posture],
Joining the Patākai gestured right hand with the stem [of the lute],
Wrapping [her hand around] a tightening instrument [with]
Knowing the clever means to eliminate the [musical] dissonances
Tying, [with] Uḻai [as] the first [and] Kaikkiḷai as the last,
The fourteen strings of an unfailing tradition,
Looking to reach the intended musical state
Of harmonious music, with these four that are called
Iṇai (‘pair’ of highest and lowest notes), Kiḷai (‘branch’ notes),
Pakai (third and sixth ‘enemy’ notes) [and] Naṭpu (four ‘friendly’ notes),
Apart from being she who heard [= learned properly]
The way of the Kural note [and] the way of the Iḻi note,
Of the five, of the seven,
Uḻai being the beginning and Uḻai being the end,
Kural being the beginning and Kural being the end,
Looking [into], so that they obtain beauty,
The four categories of types [of Marutam] -
The Akanilai Marutam, the Puṟanilai Marutam,
The Arukiyaṉ Marutam and the Perukiyaṉ Marutam,
Completing according to the traditional way, all three kinds of movements,
Outside of the creations of clear music that happened through [her] ability,
The flower-creeper [girl] becoming faint because of one song,
With pure leaves from a roll [of betel?] [with] mature, flowering screwpine,
Which was tied in the middle place with perfection, to contrasting flowers
[Which were] Campaka, Mātavi Tamālam, black-budded [but] white-petalled jasmine,
Pretty, red lotus that were closely set with fibres [= tied together with fibre]
Being the perfect one to make go a letter
By the orders of the boy with a unique justice-sceptre,
Who ruled the wide earth by means of an arrow of fragrant blossoms,
To whom the word bows, worshipping, not only in one direction,
Mixing a rich paste of red lac, taking in the hand the rich bud
Of a large-flowered jasmine nearby [as] a writing instrument, saying,
‘Even the young man - the moon - that appears on the rare nape [of the neck] of
The young king of the pleasant, young summer [season],
That makes unite living beings [into] joyous companios,
Is he who is not just;
Whether people who [once] united put time in between [= let time pass],
Whether people who have departed [= separated] forget their companion,
Deign to know this: The taking of sweet, good lives [by] [him with] fragrant, flower-arrows
Being well-acquainted musically with all sixty-four arts,
Having written extensively through immature prattling,
On passion that leads to solitude that is undone [like] the mouth of a tie,
In the tongue that criticised [through] melody and its constituents,
She with a pallid body, having called out to Vacanamālai,
Saying, ‘Having bestowed all the clear matters in [this]
Garland of pure blossoms, bring here [an answer]’,
[The girl with] long eyes [like] streaked spears
Bestowing [the letter] to Kōvalaṉ at the grain[-merchants’] street; —
‘Upon the beautiful, bright face that possessed the Tilakam mark,
The tresses, the small, black bows [= eyebrows],
The waterlilies [eyes], the Kumiḻ flower [= nose] and
The Kovvai flower [lips?] [was] the Kaṇkūṭi Vari
The Kāṇ Vari [= the dance of looking] disguise
Of she with black, long eyes that came,
[When one] says ‘come’, and go [when one] says ‘go,
Having opened a part of the hoard of coral [=mouth]
In which the The carp [=eye] having moved about on the moon [= face]
[With] overflowing rays, [it] having suffered, carrying rain-clouds [tresses],
Showing the beauty of [her] smile like young pearls
[I,] Feeling aggrieved for the coming of the twilight [in] the evening,
[She], having looked at [= noticed] [my] tender suffering
In which the pain of the mind is full,
She, being one who hides [= who is in disguise] [with]
Words that resemble a parakeet, the gait like innocence,
And the grace of a rejoicing peacock,
The Uḷ Vari dance [= the dance of disguise]
That came uniquely, in the garb of a servant-girl
With long eyes [like two] fighting spears;
The lowly Puṟa Vari dance [= dance of neglect]
Of she with a waist that does not obtain jewels,
Having looked at my suffering, that changed
That was danced standing at the back [= behind me],
So that the mouths of tinkling anklets lamented,
And so that the girdle made sound;
[She with] a good forehead having appeared
In order to strain [her] lightning waist,
[With] garlands, tresses, locks to which pollen joined,
A single, hard pearl, and the broadness of [her] breasts,
As the little, short worker-girl [= servant-girl]
Sent off a message of refusal,
The circumstance of the double-sided message
Of words that led to rivalry, which was concealed behind union,
The garb of the Kiḷar Vari dance [= the dance of intensity/exaggeration?]
That became something else that emerged,
[By her with] drooping grace [and] befitting, soft tresses;
She being one who aggrieved in the time of separation,
Apart from the Tērcci Vari dance [= the dance of examination]
In which she narrated, having deeply searched [= studied/examined]
Her own grief to my relatives;
The Kāṭci Vari dance [= the dance of the witness]
In which she narrated to onlookers/everyone [she] saw,
Bees having mingled into her opening flower-garland;
The Eṭuttukkōḷ Vari dance [= the dance of lifting her up]
That those who lifted [her] up caused to end
The faint fainting before them, one after the other;
[Oh you with] choice jewels! Because [she] is but a dancing girl
These natures [of the above dances] have been obtained
[= These dances come naturally to that [girl] with green[-gold] bracelets;’
[Kōvalaṉ], saying [thus], Vasantamālai with a faded heart,
Feeling aggrieved for the sake of the refusal of the letter on sapphire[-coloured] leaves
That were written by [she with] choice jewels
With a brilliant face that [flower-]petals adorned,
Going with haste to [she with] a garland on which petals open;
Saying, ‘Even if he does not come in the evening,
[Oh you with] eminent jewels, we will see him in the morning’,
Mātavi with long eyes like big blossoms stayed/dwelled,
Not uniting upon the flower[-strewn] bed,
